title: Company boards need directors with entrepreneurial flair
text:
Harris, who in the early 2000s decided she would not sit on boards of publicly listed companies, points to the benefits of having more people with an entrepreneurial flair sitting around the board table of private companies. It allows companies to be more innovative by taking more calculated risks.

Harris Farm director Catherine Harris says directors need time to "shoot the breeze". Supplied

“There is a difference between putting in a business strategy that doesn’t work and a business strategy that is irresponsible,” Harris says. “[In public companies, many] people don’t distinguish between bad business practices and taking a risk.

“Therein lies the problem. Maybe that is where the lack of innovation comes from. People are not prepared to take the risk. We need more entrepreneurialism.”

Having board members who have been a company boss also helps, she says. In public companies, there is often a lack of directors who have had to “sweat the payroll”.

Another lesson is creating an environment where directors feel free to put forward ideas that might be considered outside the box.

“Sitting around corporate boards are people who usually come together from different industries,” Harris says. “They don't necessarily know each other very well. There is not the bravery to throw around ideas that are out there.”

Directors, says Harris, also need time to “shoot the breeze”. This is often more difficult in public companies where there is more pressure to stick to the meeting agenda.

Harris and Morphet say private company boards tend to be closer to management, including those who operate a couple of rungs below the CEO. “In private equity, directors are more in sync with the management of the company. You get to see the talent closer,” Morphet says. “You can move more quickly if they are no good.”

Some experts argue that one of the key problems facing directors of public companies is that they don’t understand their goal. Private equity-backed company directors know they need to make money for shareholders. Not-for-profit and profit-for-member organisations, such as super funds, also have a clear core purpose.

Stakeholder focus

Investment banker and venture capitalist Mark Carnegie argues that public company directors don't have a clear goal. Too often, they get waylaid by governance issues.

He is also highly sceptical of the latest talk of directors acting in the interests of all stakeholders.

“People use ‘other stakeholders’ as a phrase to cover themselves for meetings spent on meaningless issues,” Carnegie says. “Where boards go wrong is exactly because people use a phrase like that. You can’t make it mean anything.

Advertisement

“If you want to put the environment first, say so. If you want to pay employees more, say so. If you think the management will trade the long term for the short term, then focus on that. There are heaps of things wrong with a relentless focus on profit, but using a phrase like ‘other stakeholders’ makes things worse, not better.”

Traill, who also sits on the board of Carnegie’s investment company MH Carnegie & Co, says people with strong strategic brains can be brought on as advisers and attend some, if not all, board meetings. This happens often in super funds.

At Sunsuper, former Vanguard Investments chief investment officer Gus Sauter acts as an adviser to the investment committee.

“There is a risk that compliance burden means boards are overweight with people from accounting backgrounds and not offering strategic advice,” Traill says. “[Appointing external advisers] gives you the opportunity to have people who advise on key strategic issues who don’t get tied up in the obligatory compliance side. We frequently ask advisers to board meetings.”

Traill and Carngie agree that requiring directors to have an economic interest in the company can improve their level of engagement. “My personal bias is that it’s a healthy thing,” Traill says.

Morphet says she would not make it mandatory for directors on company boards to own shares, but she says that in the private equity world it helps keep board members’ minds fixed on the job.

“Everyone knows what is going on all the time,” she says.

Carnegie also argues that directors of publicly listed companies would do well to question their motives. Too often, he argues, directors are attracted by status.

Harris notes that family company boards have greater empathy for staff, and employees tend to work harder in return. In a listed company, she says, there is not that emotional contact.
description: Private businesses have a lot to teach public companies about creating an environment where directors can suggest unorthodox ideas.
